text: Here are my suggestions. I copied and pasted your whole statement and then added and deleted where I thought necessary so you can compare between your original:

There are moments in every person’s life where you are not sure what is right or wrong. Then we come across an incident where our life is completely changed. Recently, I had to undergo surgery, which involved an MRI scan. Before, I did not have the slightest clue about radiography or its role in the medical field. I can now say that an MRI scanner is a large tube that contains powerful magnets, where the patient lies inside the tube during the scan, and I gained this knowledge first hand from my serendipitous experience.

This is all thanks to the radiographer who helped me after my incident, because they really inspired me and gave me a glimpse of what it might be like to be a radiographer. Viewing the photographs of my own scan was fascinating. Through the radiographer's eyes, I saw and felt the passion they had toward their role and how they managed their challenging career. Not just passion but I saw the dedication and hard work involved; the radiographer was working with so much enthusiasm and diligence. I asked a few questions regarding the MRI procedure, and the radiographer spoke with so much intensity and knowledge, it was as if he had invented it the procedure. I learnt about his thought processes as he added that he came across the right decision after experimenting with many other decisions. The radiographer added that "the mechanical equipment has developed a lot throughout the history’’ and so it would be very interesting to be part of such a developing field. Having to experience an MRI scan is the reason of my decision to choose this course.

The Radiographer’s responsibilities towards their patients are immense as they have to inform the patients of certain health hazards. I am currently studying BTEC Science Level 3 and as part of this coursework in the unit Medical Physics Applications, has enabled me to know more about the benefits and issues involved in the field.
In 2016 I attended an event at Imperial College for future potential surgeons. During this event, I had an opportunity to learn about a typical doctor’s life, such as performing suture, CPR and knowing the risks and complications of surgery. Team work and problem-solving skills were applied when doing a group activity with people of different age groups and it was a thoroughly thought-provoking and interesting day. Furthermore, I was part of a voluntary group at a local community charity. This helped me to gain leadership skills whilst I helped young children doing outdoor activities. In school, I relished being a pair mentor as I was able to help KS3 students with reading. I carried out a lot of responsibilities whilst working with young children. 
As a volunteer at health watch, my role was to document patient experience information. This was done by doing surveys and recording the information in the system. As part of this volunteering, I did surveys suggesting that the radiographer needs a lot of patience when working with people. Volunteering at a local community pharmacy enabled me to develop my communicating skills as I had to approach customers and collect patient’s prescription record. Moreover, attending summer camp I the local community helped me to develop my self-motivation skills as I had the opportunity to do photography, dance, and visit care homes. All of this voluntary work has helped me to experience many things I wouldn’t have got to experience otherwise and has opened my eyes to the opportunities out there involved with caring for people.

In my spare time, I like to be creative by doing paintings and I also enjoy reading blogs about history and food. 
My hobbies also include exploring learning languages including French and Korean. I am fluent in Konkani as it is my native language and also fluent in English and Hindi. I believe that knowing these languages will help me to communicate with people from different ethnic backgrounds, further benefitting my communication skills. Growing up in this century, I realise that photography is part of my daily routine and has given me a good attention to detail and an eye for viewing images, which is intrinsically important for a radiographer. 

I thoroughly believe that I have the passion and motivation to study radiography at university and my hard work and school background will make me a strong and capable radiographer.
